metadata.case_name: Members of Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bahraich v. Sunni Central Board of Waqf, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh

facts.text: Shrine and tomb known as Darga Hazarat Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi situated in village Singha Parasi with appurtenant properties.

Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi, nephew of Muhammad Ghazni, died at hands of local chieftain in Bahraich; remains buried in Singha Parasi, tomb constructed, became pilgrimage site with annual Urs and offerings.
Properties endowed by Emperors of Delhi; accretions from savings of income and offerings.
Tomb managed by Khuddams of the Darga performing ceremonies and services.
Oudh annexed in 1856; proclamation by Lord Canning confiscated private properties and inams including Darga properties.
Fresh settlements revived rights; Sanad granted to Fakirulla (head of khadims) in 1859 or 1860 for rent-free tenure of village Singha Parasi, usufruct for Darga maintenance.

Inayatulla (Fakirulla's son) filed Suit No. 1 of 1865 claiming proprietary rights; dismissed by Settlement Officer on November 11, 1870; proprietary rights vested in charity, Inayatulla's management rights recognized.
1872 complaint of mismanagement by khadims; Committee of Mussalmans appointed, reported February 20, 1877, recommended jury of five including two khadims.
Government took possession under Pensions Act XXIII of 1873 after Deputy Commissioner report August 31, 1878; freed properties from mortgages.

Government management continued until 1902; Inayatulla suit in 1892 for possession of Darga, buildings, village; trial court decreed, appellate court (Judicial Commissioner) set aside July 20, 1897; held Government interference improper under Religious Endowments Act XX of 1863.
Government suit No. 9 of 1902 under s.539 CPC (present s.92); decree December 3, 1902 declared properties vest in trustees when appointed, scheme framed for management.
Scheme operated smoothly until 1934.

Suit No. 1 of 1934 by Ashraf Ali others for injunction against defendants in management, prohibit spending waqf funds on litigation; District Judge order May 7, 1934 no spending without court sanction.

Suit No. 1 of 1940 with Advocate-General sanction against managing committee/trustees for removal and fresh scheme; decreed October 16, 1941; appeal succeeded March 7, 1946, decree set aside with minor amendments.
United Provinces Muslim Waqfs Act U.P. XIII of 1936 passed.
Sunni Central Board (respondent 1) constituted; notification February 26, 1944 under s.5(1) declaring properties Sunni Waqf.
Board called for budget, audit, levied contributions under s.54.

Appellants (members of Waqf Committee except two trustees as pro forma defendants) filed suit Regular Suit No. 25 of 1946 on October 18, 1946 claiming declaration properties not covered by Act, injunction against Board.

Trial court (Civil Judge Bahraich) held properties not waqf under Act, suit within time via Limitation Act s.14, partial bar under s.53; decree April 15, 1947 declaration and injunction granted partially.

Respondent 1 appealed to Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench F.C. Appeal No. 50 of 1947; appellants cross-objections; High Court reversed, held waqf under Act, barred by s.52 limitation and no s.53 notice; suit dismissed April 22, 1953.
Certificate under Art. 133 Constitution granted for SC appeal.

legal_issues.text: Are the properties in suit governed by the United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act, U.P. XIII of 1936?
Is the suit barred by limitation under s.52 of the Act?
Is the suit maintainable without notice under s.53 of the Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Properties in suit are outside operative provisions of the Act, not waqf as defined; respondent 1 acted illegally without jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.2

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit not barred by s.52 as appellants neither mutawallis nor persons interested in waqf (deny waqf existence); s.52 inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.52; Limitation Act s.14, s.15

petitioner_arguments.text: Time excluded under Limitation Act s.15 due to order in Suit No.1/1940 staying institution.
Notification did not cover Darga and offerings; s.53 notice not required for those properties.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.53

respondent_arguments.text: Properties form waqf as defined by Act; duly constituted Board authorised to supervise.
Suit barred by one-year limitation under s.52 from notification February 26, 1944.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.52

respondent_arguments.text: Suit incompetent without statutory notice under s.53.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.53

court_reasoning.text: Declines to decide if properties waqf under Act as suit barred by s.52 and incompetent under s.53; treats as preliminary objections assuming properties outside Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unnecessary to decide merits if limitation/s.53 upheld.

court_reasoning.text: s.52 applies; 'any person interested in a waqf' means interested in transaction held to be waqf; literal construction would make provision meaningless; appellants interested in notified properties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of s.52 contemplates challenge by those disputing Commissioner's decision.

court_reasoning.text: Limitation Act s.15 inapplicable; requires injunction/order expressly or impliedly staying suit institution; prior order in 1940 suit did not stay this suit (cause arose later). Strict construction, no equity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No order staying institution; filing suit not futile to stop limitation.

court_reasoning.text: s.53 applies; notification covered Darga (expressly named), offerings as income; notice required for suits against Board re acts under Act or relief re waqf; not given.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notification under s.5(1) included tomb; offerings inherently income.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants' plaint admits waqf but claims exemption under s.2(ii)(a),(c); inconsistent with denying waqf for s.52.

holdings.text: Suit governed by and barred by one-year limitation in s.52(2) proviso from notification date.
Limitation Act s.15 does not save suit; no injunction/order staying institution.
Suit not maintainable without two-month notice under s.53 to Board.

statutes_cited.relevance: Governs waqfs, survey, notification, Board powers, limitation for challenging waqf status, notice requirement; suit barred thereunder

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld High Court decree setting aside trial court decree and dismissing suit; held suit barred by limitation under s.52 and not maintainable without notice under s.53 of U.P. Muslims Waqfs Act 1936; did not decide if properties waqf under Act.

key_quotes.text: "the expression any person interested in a waqf must mean any person interested in what is held to be a waqf."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation applying s.52 limitation to challengers denying waqf status

key_quotes.text: "in construing the provisions of a statute courts should be slow to adopt a construction which tends to make any part of the statute meaningless or ineffective"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle for liberal construction of s.52

key_quotes.text: "the institution of a suit can never be said to be futile if it would thereby prevent the running of limitation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Privy Council; strict application of Limitation Act s.15
